Well, yes a method like this would be nice:
assertEquals(File f1, File f2)
Is there some extension to JUnit that contains such a method ?
(yes, I know it would be easy to do it yourself, but prefer to reuse 
existing code instead of reinventing the wheel)

But I also think it would be useful (to get more complete failure 
messages) with a more generic class that you can use within a loop to 
gather differences instead of immediately failing on the first 
difference
(as I illsutrated with my code sample).


/ Tom


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@d...> wrote:
> > For example, if I will parse two files and compare row by row, I
> > would like to see all the differences and not just the first
> > difference.
> 
> Sounds to me like you want to compare two files, and not rows - in 
a similar
> way that assertEquals for Strings doesn't just fail on the first 
difference
> in a character.
> 
> With other words, what you probably want to do/look for, is an 
assert method
> that gathers all differences in two files and then fails with an 
appropriate
> message if there are any.
> 
> Does that sound reasonable?
> 
> Cheers, Ilja
